title: 106_s517
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999". It pertains to emergency services. The "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999" requires group health plans and health insurance coverage to cover emergency services without prior authorization, regardless of the provider's participation status, to protect participants from liability. The "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999" mandates that group health plans and insurance coverage must cover emergency services without prior authorization, regardless of provider participation status, to protect participants from excessive liability. The "Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999" requires coverage of emergency medical conditions and services without prior authorization to protect individuals from excessive liability. An emergency medical condition is defined as acute symptoms requiring immediate attention to prevent specified outcomes under the Social Security Act. The term "to stabilize" means providing necessary medical examination and treatment to stabilize a patient with an emergency medical condition as required under the Social Security Act. The provision of medical treatment for an emergency condition is necessary to prevent deterioration during transfer. Reimbursement for non-emergency services must be consistent with guidelines and provided even if not through a participating healthcare provider. Group health plans must comply with guidelines for maintenance and post-stabilization care. They are required to provide information to participants and beneficiaries at the start of coverage. Group health plans must provide information to participants and beneficiaries at the start of coverage and annually thereafter. Health insurance issuers must also provide information to individuals enrolled in coverage at enrollment and annually thereafter. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must provide information about emergency services, including appropriate use, to participants, beneficiaries, plan administrators, prospective enrollees, and the public in printed form upon request. The section outlines the requirements for providing information on emergency services, including appropriate use, procedures for obtaining services, cost-sharing, and locations of emergency departments and other settings for care. The term "authority" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of Labor, or the applicable State authority enforcing specific provisions. "Nonparticipating" describes a health care provider not participating in a group health plan or health insurance. The term "participating" refers to a health care provider that furnishes items and services under a contract with a group health plan or health insurance issuer. Other terms such as "applicable State authority", "beneficiary", "group health plan", "health insurance coverage", "health insurance issuer", and "participant" have specific meanings as defined in section 2791. The term "participating" refers to a health care provider that furnishes items and services under a contract with a group health plan or health insurance issuer, with specific meanings defined in section 2791 of the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 2707 of the Public Health Service Act addresses emergency services in the group market. Each group health plan and health insurance issuer offering group coverage must comply with the Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999. Notice requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act apply to group health plans and health insurance issuers in the individual market. Each health insurance issuer offering individual coverage must comply with the Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999. Notice requirements under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act apply to health insurance issuers in the individual market. SEC. 714 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, as amended by the Omnibus Consolidated and Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act, 1999, addresses emergency services. Subject to subsection (b), a group health plan and health insurance issuer offering group coverage must comply with the Access to Emergency Medical Services Act of 1999. If a plan provides benefits through an issuer, it is considered to meet the Act's requirements as long as the plan sponsor did not cause any failure by the issuer. Section 732(a) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include "sections 711 and 714". The table of contents in the Act is also updated to reflect this change. SEC. 5. STANDARDS UNDER THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE OF 1986: Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new standard relating to emergency services in group health plans. 

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. Group health coverage amendments apply to plans starting on or after January 1, 2000, except for those under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment date. The amendment applies to health insurance coverage in the individual market starting on or after January 1, 2000, with exceptions for collective bargaining agreements.
